channel.title: ALU on Relay Computer
channel.description: Recent content in ALU on Relay Computer

item.title: ALU & Registers A-D Test with new Display Cards
item.description: Now that the two display cards are complete enough to display and control the status of the ALU and four registers (A-D) it’s time to fit them to the upper enclosure.

item.title: Completed ALU
item.description: Following my last post on the completed backplane I’m now in a position to connect all the other completed cards together to test the full ALU.

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Backplane
item.description: In my last post I mentioned I’d suffered a bit of a set back with the construction of the ALU backplane. Well, the short version of things is that I’ve admitted defeat and constructed a new backplane using a different design … it looks like this:

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Control Card Full Test
ALU Construction: Control Card Power Rails & Wire Wrap
item.description: I’ve been a bit short of time lately so I’ve been working on the ALU Control Card in little bursts … but after lots of these little bursts I’ve now got all the power rails and wire wrap done for this card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Control Card Header Pins & Relay Sockets
item.description: Following on from the first two successfully completed ALU cards, for logic and arithmetic, it’s time to make a start on the control card (well, actually, the LEDs and connectors are already done from earlier but you get the gist).

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Arithmetic Card Full Test
ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Wire Wrap 2
item.description: I’ve managed to squeeze in a couple more wire wrapping sessions this week so in this post there’s a few photos of progress so far.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Wire Wrap 1
item.description: Fear not (just in case you were for some reason) all this talk of Sketchup and enclosures and so on hasn’t totally diverted me from the main task of constructing the ALU.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Power Rails
item.description: Another round of soldering done … this time putting down the power rails on the arithmetic card along with some soldered wire links. This is the last of the soldering for this card - it’s all wire wrapping form hereon in.

item.title: ALU Construction: 1-bit Arithmetic Full Construction
item.description: So, as mentioned in my last post this time I’ve put in the wire links and wraps needed to test the first bit of the arithmetic card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Relay Sockets
item.description: It’s always a fiddly job getting the relay sockets soldered in and the ALU arithmetic card proved no exception. With this in mind I’ve been spreading the work out over several mini sessions in accordance with my new post-Xmas lack of patience.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Header Pins
item.description: Following on from the successful construction of the ALU logic card in my last post it’s time to start off the new year with the next ALU card (number 2 of 3 ALU cards in total) … the arithmetic card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Logic Card Full Test
item.description: The ALU logic card is now finally complete! … well, it is now I’ve popped the last few relays into their sockets. The final card looks like this:

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 3
item.description: I’m now just one session of wire wrapping away from a completed ALU logic card. The final job is to wire up the gating relays that select one of the five logic results back on to the data bus.

item.title: ALU Construction: 8-bit Logic Unit Tests
item.description: There’s now enough sockets, solder and wires to test all eight bits of the ALU logic card. This isn’t quite a full test as the gating relays that apply one of the results produced by each bit unit haven’t been wired up yet but there’s enough there to be able to set an input and see the results displayed on the LEDs along the front of the card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 2
item.description: Continuing on with the wire wrapping for the ALU logic card next up is the input and result links: {% figure %} {% endfigure %}

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 1
item.description: Finally, with all the soldering now done, it’s time to set about wire wrapping the ALU logic card. First up is the internal connections within each logic bit:

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Power Rails
item.description: It seems that every time I move on to the next stage of construction on the ALU logic card it’s fiddlier than the stage before it … this stage is no exception.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Relay Sockets
item.description: The construction of the ALU logic card is coming along nicely but there’s still a lot of soldering ahead to get all the relay sockets down … and this part is the fiddliest bit yet.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Header Pins
item.description: Following on from the successful construction of the first bit on the ALU logic card in my last post it’s now time to start putting together the other 7 bits and the gating circuits (to place one of the logic results on to the data bus).

item.title: ALU Construction: 1-bit Logic Full Construction
item.description: So, although I probably should construct the logic card methodically a full stage at a time (solder header pins then sockets then wire wrap) I can’t resist fully assembling a single bit alone to see if/how it works.

item.title: ALU Construction: LED Tests
item.description: Following on from my last post I can now test the LEDs that have been soldered and hooked up to the header pins on each of the three ALU cards (Logic, Arithmetic and Control).

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Links
item.description: Before I can test all of the LEDs laid down so far (to make sure they survived the heat of the soldering iron) I need to add some wire links on the logic card between the LED anodes and the header pins.

item.title: ALU Construction: LED Header Pins
item.description: So far, in the construction of the three ALU cards (Logic, Arithmetic and Control) I’ve soldered down the connectors and LEDs. It’s now time to solder in some header pins and join them to the existing connectors and LEDs ready for wire-wrapping later.

item.title: ALU Construction: Connectors and LEDs
item.description: As promised in my last post it’s finally time to get the soldering iron out and make a start on constructing the three cards that make up the ALU.

item.title: ALU Design: Control Unit
item.description: In the last three posts I introduced the design for the 3-to-8 Function Decoder, Zero Detect circuit and the Condition Registers. In this post I’ll put all three of these components together to make up the ALU Control Card.

item.title: ALU Design: Condition Registers
item.description: This post covers the design of the ALU Condition Registers which along with the 3-to-8 Function Decoder and Zero Detect circuit (both covered in my previous posts) make up the ALU Control Card.

item.title: ALU Design: Zero Detect
item.description: This post covers the design of the Zero Detect circuit which along with the 3-to-8 Function Decoder (covered in my last post) and the Condition Registers (next post) make up the ALU Control Card.

item.title: ALU Design: Function Decoder
item.description: This post covers the design of a 3-to-8 Function Decoder which along with the Zero Detect circuit and Condition Registers will all go in to the ALU Control Card.

item.title: ALU Design: 8-bit Arithmetic Unit
item.description: In the last post I introduced the design for the 1-bit Arithmetic Unit. This post covers connecting eight of these units together to make an 8-bit Arithmetic Unit along with result gating and increment functionality.

item.title: ALU Design: 1-bit Arithmetic Unit
item.description: This post covers the design of a 1-bit Arithmetic Unit that can add two input bits together (B and C) with carry in and out. Here’s a schematic of the 1-bit Arithmetic Unit (based directly on the one used in the Harry Porter Relay Computer):

item.title: ALU Design: 8-bit Logic Unit
item.description: In the last post I introduced the design for a 1-bit Logic Unit. This post covers the design effort to cram 8 of these on to a single pad board complete with connectors, status LEDs and gating relays thereby forming a complete 8-bit Logic Unit.

item.title: ALU Design: 1-bit Logic Unit
item.description: This post covers the design of a 1-bit Logic Unit that can produce AND, OR, XOR, NOT and SHL (Shift Left) outputs from two input bits B and C.

item.title: Architectural breakdown: the ALU
item.description: In this post I’ll continue to try and explain away the various bits of the architecture that will make up my relay computer project â€” this time it’s the Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU).
